author: complex.com
title: Mikal Bridges Says He's Eaten Chipotle Every Day for 10 Years
text:
Nets' Mikal Bridges Says He's Eaten Chipotle Every Day for Last Decade: 'It's Too Fire' The Nets star also broke down his go-to order.
By Joe Price You mean the movie lied? Dec 28, 2023
youtube.com youtube subscribe button icon
SUBSCRIBE ON YOUTUBE View this video on YouTube youtube.com Chipotle megafan Mikal Bridges says he's eaten food from the chain every day for the past ten years or so.
In an interview with GQ Sports about his essentials, which also included his favorite sneakers and his dog Sonny, the Brooklyn Nets star made the stunning revelation and once again reiterated his position as the NBA's biggest Chipotle fan. "Chipotle, I eat this every day and it's been about... How many years since I've been eating Chipotle? Since 2013-14, so about ten years," he said. "Still been on it heavy to this day. I have friends and family that teases me a little bit about it. It's too fire to not have it every single time. So, it don't disappoint."
Bridges expressed his enthusiasm for the chain and took a bite of his custom order, which he broke down. "So, my bowl order, I get white rice, no beans, double chicken, medium and mild salsa. Corn and lettuce," he explained. "Oh, I used to get the hot salsa. But I don't know if y'all know that hot salsa. I don't know what they did to it in [these] past couple years, but I'll just take one bite, I'd just be like, chugging water and it still ain't helping. It just be painful eating a bowl."
Bridges admitted that he's felt disappointed by his aversion to the hot salsa, because he's always considered himself a big fan of spicy food. "I felt soft because I love spicy food, and I'm just like, bro, I've been eating this hot sauce for all these years," he added. "Rest in peace to the hot sauce."
In 2018, the same year he was traded to the Phoenix Suns after being drafted by the Philadelphia 76ers, Bridges shared his love of Chipotle with the world in a simple tweet. "Im your biggest fan @ChipotleTweets," he wrote.
Im your biggest fan ðŸ™‹ðŸ¾â€â™‚ï¸ @ChipotleTweets
â€” Mikal Bridges (@mikal_bridges) June 23, 2018 Twitter: @mikal_bridges In an interview with CloseUp360 in 2020, he went into it further. "I remember in the summer we went every single day,â€ he said. "Like we would work out and stuff and then go and get Chipotle every single day." He might be playing a risky game, but it seems to be working out for him.

author: Kate Hwang, Graduate Desk Editor
title: An Irish Poetâ€™s Landmark in Literature Revealed in New Lau 5 Poetry Exhibition
text:
A recent Georgetown graduate
curated a new exhibition in Lauinger Library on renowned Irish poet Paul Muldoon.
Chris Kennyâ€™s (GRD â€™23) â€œPaul Muldoon: The Joseph M. Hassett Collection,â€ which lies outside the Booth Family Center for Special Collections, is open for
viewing from March 1 to May 31, giving students, staff and faculty the opportunity to examine Muldoonâ€™s poetry and contemporary Irish history. The Paul Muldoon exhibition began as a project to catalog a donation from Joseph M. Hassett â€“ an author currently based in Washington, D.C. â€“ which compiles Muldoonâ€™s rare, limited-edition works.
Kenny said that it was a challenge to create the poetry exhibition since it was his first time doing this type of project.
â€œI donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve been to a book exhibit before doing this, so it was definitely a challenge,â€ Kenny told The Hoya. â€œAfter I was assigned to do it, I went to a bunch of book exhibits to see what they were like, but it just introduced me to that whole world.â€
Muldoon, whom the Times Literary Supplement
recognized as â€œthe most significant English-language poet born since the Second World Warâ€ and a 2003 recipient of the Pulitzer Prize in Poetry, is prominent in modern Irish literature and poetry and provides profound insights into postcolonial history, according to Kenny.
CÃ³ilÃ­n Parsons, an associate professor in the English department, said he introduced Kenny to this book curating project upon discovering his notable attentiveness to literature.
â€œChris was taking a class I taught on Joyceâ€™s Ulysses, and I was struck by his deep love of literature and his facility for reading with care and pleasure,â€ Parsons wrote to The Hoya. â€œI asked him whether he would be interested in the cataloging job and it took off from there.â€
Jay Sylvestre, a curator at the Booth Family Center for Special Collections who collaborated closely with Kenny on the exhibition, said he and Kenny focused on making Muldoonâ€™s written work appear visually appealing.
â€œThe big challenge for Chris and for myself was to take a lot of written material and try to make it interesting in a visual manner,â€ Sylvestre told The Hoya. â€œWe were really fortunate that Muldoon often partners with artists and musicians, and with Chris knowing a lot of Muldoonâ€™s work and a lot of his partnerships and collaboration, we were able to find some really interesting and visually appealing images to put in the case to complement the poetry.â€
Kenny said the creative process behind the curation of Paul Muldoonâ€™s poetry collection included various hands-on experiments to bring the art to life.
â€œFirst thing was just to sit in the beautiful reading room at Special Collections and read everything and try to find a few sticking points that jumped out as kind of crucial moments in the life and work of this poet,â€ Kenny said.
Sylvestre emphasized the high level of detail and attention in curating the Muldoon Hassett collection as they experimented with different book stands and layouts.
â€œWe would sit down in our classroom with books he was thinking about putting in the exhibit, and we would get book supports and lay things out on the table and adjust levels and put things on risers to see how they might look in the exhibition case and that was a much more hands-on process,â€ Sylvestre said.
Kenny said he found the process of creating the exhibition eye-opening as a different approach to Muldoonâ€™s work other than his thesis.
â€œWhen youâ€™re writing a thesis a lot of times it can be hard, you canâ€™t see the light at the end of the tunnel and you just get lost in all of these threads of different arguments,â€ Kenny said. â€œBut one way I learned through doing this â€” that helps you find your way out of that sort of labyrinth â€” is by going out into the world and seeing book exhibits.â€
Parsons said the exhibition effectively displays Muldoonâ€™s writing process as the reader can track the lifespan of Muldoonâ€™s works.
â€œI think one of the great things about a collection like this is that we get to see not only the lifespan (so far, since Muldoon is still writing) of the poetâ€™s work, but also the life span of individual poems,â€ Parsons wrote. â€œBuilt into the collection are reprints and emendations, showing how a poem moves from pen to page.â€
Parsons encouraged students to enjoy the beauty of Muldoonâ€™s works, especially since the collection in the library holds some of Muldoonâ€™s most notable works.
â€œI would love students to enjoy the beauty of these books,â€ Parsons wrote. â€œJoe [Hassett] has taken such good care of them, and has collected them so deliberately, that this is one of the most important collections of Muldoon published items in the US.â€
â€œEver attuned to nuance and multiple meanings, his poems offer us a masterclass in how to experience, with pleasure and confusion, and reflect on the many-faceted world around us,â€ Parsons added.
Kenny recommended students engage with the Muldoon poetry exhibition by looking beyond the words on the page and delving into its context.
â€œPick a poem that you see that jumps out at you or an image and look at it and read about the context immediately surrounding that,â€ Kenny said.

author: Infrastructure Canada
title: Federal government invests in coastal protection project in Lax Kwâ€™alaams - Canada.ca
text:
From: Infrastructure Canada
News release Measures are being put in place to stabilize the shoreline in Lax Kwâ€™alaams after an investment of more than $5 million from the federal government. Announced by Minister Jonathan Wilkinson, this project will protect the communityâ€™s critical infrastructure and preserve the precious habitats of important fish species, such as surf smelt and herring.
Lax Kwâ€™alaams, British Columbia, February 15, 2024 â€” Measures are being put in place to stabilize the shoreline in Lax Kwâ€™alaams after an investment of more than $5 million from the federal government. Announced by Minister Jonathan Wilkinson, this project will protect the communityâ€™s critical infrastructure and preserve the precious habitats of important fish species, such as surf smelt and herring.
Located on the northwest coast, and accessible only by ferry or water taxi, Lax Kwâ€™alaams is experiencing a consistently high rate of erosion along its shoreline, caused by a rise in sea level, storm surges, and strong winds. This has resulted in the loss of a considerable amount of land, putting the communityâ€™s power, roads, water and sanitary sewer assets at risk. Funding will go towards the construction of new rock revetments along the shoreline to create a barrier to absorb and dissipate the wave energy of the water, which will in turn protect Lax Kwâ€™alaams against further erosion.
Making adaptation investments now will have major economy-wide benefits later. Every dollar that is invested in adapting and preparing for climate-related disasters can return as much as $13 to $15 in benefits.
Quotes â€œEmpowering communities to combat climate change is the foundation to building a stable economy and healthy communities. This investment will reinforce preservation of our unique coastal ecology and empower the Lax Kwâ€™alaams community to combat erosion damage. The federal government will continue to keep investing in projects to keep our communities secure and help keep families safe for years to come.â€
The Honourable Jonathan Wilkinson, Minister of Energy and Natural Resources of Canada, on behalf of the Honourable Sean Fraser, Minister of Housing, Infrastructure and Communities
â€œThis project will help protect the shorelines of Rose Island and the causeway that connects the island to the community. The houses, roads, parks and infrastructure on Rose Island will see added protection from coastal erosion, now and for future generations of Lax Kw'alaams residents.â€
Garry Reece, Mayor of Lax Kw'alaams Band
Quick facts The federal government is investing $5,038,000 in this project through the Disaster Mitigation and Adaptation Fund (DMAF).
Since 2018, the federal government has committed over $3.8 billion to the Disaster Mitigation and Adaptation Fund.
To date, over $2.4 billion has been announced for more than 91 infrastructure projects that help communities better prepare for, and withstand, the potential impacts of natural disasters, prevent infrastructure failures, and help keep Canadians safe.
This funding will support projects that include new construction of public infrastructure or the modification or reinforcement of existing public infrastructure that help communities withstand natural disasters and climate-related risks.
Eligible recipients include municipalities, local governments, provinces and territories, public sector bodies, Indigenous organizations, not-for-profit, and for-profit organizations in partnership with other eligible applicants outside the private sector. Projects must have a minimum of $1 million in total eligible costs to be considered eligible.
On November 24 th , 2022, the federal government released Canadaâ€™s National Adaptation Strategy: Building Resilient Communities and a Strong Economy . It commits $1.6 billion in new federal funding to help address both immediate and future climate risks to Canadian communities.
As part of the Adaptation Action Plan, released alongside the National Adaptation Strategy, the Disaster Mitigation and Adaptation Fund received an additional $489.1 million in funding.
Federal funding is conditional on fulfilling all requirements related to consultation with Indigenous groups and environmental assessment obligations.
Associated links Disaster Mitigation and Adaptation Fund Canadaâ€™s National Adaptation Strategy Strengthened Climate Plan Investing in Canada Plan Project Map Federal infrastructure investments in B.C. Contacts For more information (media only), please contact:
Micaal Ahmed
Communications Manager
Office of the Minister of Housing, Infrastructure and Communities
343-598-3920

author: (Nina JareÃ±o)
title: La estabilizaciÃ³n tartÃ¡rica sin aditivos de Oenodia crece en EspaÃ±a
text:
Rentable, eco-responsable y segura, asÃ­ es la tecnologÃ­a que ya revoluciona la estabilizaciÃ³n en el mundo
La estabilizaciÃ³n tartÃ¡rica sin aditivos de Oenodia crece en EspaÃ±a
Oenodia se estÃ¡ convirtiendo en una de las empresas que marca el futuro de la enologÃ­a. Gracias a su gama de equipos eco-eficientes de estabilizaciÃ³n tartÃ¡rica y cÃ¡lcica, de filtraciÃ³n, de ajuste del pH y de desalcoholizaciÃ³n parcial, su presencia en EspaÃ±a no para de crecer. En el marco de Enomaq, pudimos conversar con los cuatro representantes de la firma francesa en EspaÃ±a para que nos explicaran cÃ³mo funciona la estabilizaciÃ³n tartÃ¡rica por membranas para ofrecer unos resultados sin igual, con grandes ahorros energÃ©ticos y garantÃ­a de estabilidad.
La estabilizaciÃ³n tartÃ¡rica por electrodiÃ¡lisis es una tecnologÃ­a en auge y Oenodia es uno de los mayores exponentes de este crecimiento. Bajo el nombre de STARS, la gama de equipos de estabilizaciÃ³n tartÃ¡rica y de ajuste del pH por membranas no solamente estabiliza y acidifica, sino que lo hace sin aditivos. Se trata de un mÃ©todo fÃ­sico, una alternativa al uso de insumos y productos que estÃ¡n actualmente en el mercado que destaca por no afectar a las cualidades organolÃ©pticas de ningÃºn vino.
Sin pÃ©rdidas de vino y sin disoluciÃ³n de oxÃ­geno, y siempre preservando el color, STARS es eco-eficiente: el consumo de energÃ­a se reduce en un 95% y los costes de operaciÃ³n son entre un 60 y un 80% mÃ¡s bajos que con el tratamiento por frÃ­o. AsÃ­, STARS es eficiente desde el punto de vista energÃ©tico (tan solo consume 0,2 kilovatios por hectolitro de vino), eco-selectiva (solo se eliminan del vino los iones responsables de la inestabilidad tartÃ¡rica y cÃ¡lcica) y de alto rendimiento.
En Enomaq, Oenodia reuniÃ³ a sus representantes espaÃ±oles: Tecnoequip, Salvador Cores, SYS Oenological y Secovisa.
La compaÃ±Ã­a, que cuenta con una larga trayectoria en el mundo enolÃ³gico y estÃ¡ implantada en paÃ­ses tan importantes en el sector del vino como Francia e Italia, hace unos aÃ±os que estÃ¡ apostando fuerte por EspaÃ±a. Y no lo hace solo, sino de la mano de representantes estratÃ©gicos por las distintas zonas productoras del paÃ­s.
â€œEn EspaÃ±a, mÃ¡s allÃ¡ de las especificaciones tÃ©cnicas, se vende por confianza y el servicio de proximidad es lo mÃ¡s importanteâ€, nos dijo Flor Etchebarne, delegada comercial de Oenodia durante la feria Enomaq. â€œNosotros somos conscientes de ello y por eso le damos tanto valor a nuestros representantes, porque son quienes estÃ¡n en el territorio, cerca de las bodegas, prestando servicio antes y despuÃ©s, y son quienes conocen las necesidades y las demandas reales de nuestros clientesâ€, aseverÃ³.
Reciente instalaciÃ³n de un equipo STARS en una bodega de la DO Rueda.
Entre estos representantes, destaca la empresa Tecnoequip, que comercializa los productos y servicios de Oenodia en Catalunya, Comunidad Valenciana y Baleares. Su director, Pere Canals, nos explicÃ³ su estrecha relaciÃ³n con la firma francesa: â€œGracias a la colaboraciÃ³n con Oenodia, en 2009 constituimos Gemstab WS en EspaÃ±a, dedicada exclusivamente a la prestaciÃ³n de servicios a bodegas con unidades mÃ³viles por todo el paÃ­s. Juntos, somos especialistas en la filtraciÃ³n tangencial y estabilizaciÃ³n tartÃ¡rica a medida de la necesidad del clienteâ€.
Si bien Canals reconoce que, â€œal principio, la tecnologÃ­a fue difÃ­cil de implantarâ€, en 2009 llegÃ³ la primera unidad mÃ³vil a EspaÃ±a, en 2017 la segunda y ahora ya estÃ¡n trabajando en la tercera: â€œTras el covid hemos recibido bastantes solicitudes y notamos un creciente interÃ©s por parte del sector, hay mÃ¡s demandaâ€, aÃ±adiÃ³.
Pero si hay algo que Canals tiene claro es que â€œel factor principal que mÃ¡s destacan nuestros clientes a largo plazo es la seguridad que ofrecen nuestros equipos, lo que se traduce en tranquilidad y garantÃ­a de calidadâ€.
Flor Etchebarne, delegada comercial de Oenodia, nos recibiÃ³ en su stand junto a Pere Canals, director de Tecnoequip y Gemstab WS.
En Galicia, el representante estratÃ©gico es Salvador Cores. Su director comercial, AdriÃ¡n Cores, nos contÃ³ que la relaciÃ³n entre ambas empresas naciÃ³ hace ya unos 7 aÃ±os y juntos han logrado que Galicia sea una de las zonas donde se ve mÃ¡s evoluciÃ³n y mÃ¡s demanda de las soluciones de Oenodia, especialmente porque muchas pequeÃ±as bodegas productoras de vino de alta calidad se interesan por las unidades mÃ³viles de GEMSTAB.
â€œEs cierto que la estabilizaciÃ³n por membranas es una tecnologÃ­a muy reciente para el mercado espaÃ±ol, pero en Galicia estÃ¡ siendo bien aceptada y cada aÃ±o aumentamos el nÃºmero de bodegas que solicitan el servicio mÃ³vil. Tanto es asÃ­ que incluso tenemos demandas para implantar mÃ¡quinas propiasâ€, nos dijo.
En este sentido, tal vez el dato mÃ¡s interesante en el mercado gallego es el retorno: â€œEl 100% de bodegas que prueban el servicio GEMSTAB, repiten. La mayorÃ­a, incluso empiezan trabajando con alguno de sus vinos y acaban aplicÃ¡ndolo en toda su producciÃ³nâ€, puntualizÃ³ Cores.
â€œY esto no es porquÃ© sÃ­â€, continuÃ³, sino por el grado de detalle con el que se trabaja: â€œEl sistema analiza previamente, estabiliza y analiza de nuevo para que los resultados sean completamente fiablesâ€, subrayÃ³. â€œMediante un test, se determina previamente el grado de inestabilidad tartÃ¡rica de cada vino y asÃ­ se puede establecer una tasa de tratamiento extremadamente precisa. Una vez estabilizado, se vuele a comprobar mediante otro test la eficacia del tratamiento, que suele ser extremadamente exacto y seguro, ademÃ¡s de muy duradero en el tiempoâ€.
Las unidades mÃ³viles de Gemstab WS realizan tratamientos enolÃ³gicos a domicilio.
Igual que Galicia, Castilla y LeÃ³n tambiÃ©n estÃ¡ expandiendo su interÃ©s por esta tecnologÃ­a de la mano del representante SYS Oenological, que distribuye desde hace 6 aÃ±os las soluciones de Oenodia, con una interesante aceptaciÃ³n de los servicios GEMSTAB. â€œAcabamos de comercializar el primer equipo de estabilizaciÃ³n propio a una bodega muy importante de la zona y sabemos que esto nos va a abrir muchas puertasâ€, nos explicÃ³ convencida Laura FernÃ¡ndez, directora de SYS Oenological.
â€œEl mundo de la enologÃ­a ha evolucionado muchÃ­simo en EspaÃ±a, un mercado en el que Rioja lideraba en todos los sentidos, pero donde los demÃ¡s Ã­bamos muy por detrÃ¡s. En la dÃ©cada de los 2000, todo cambiÃ³ y ahora estÃ¡ mucho mÃ¡s profesionalizado todo el paÃ­s, somos mucho mÃ¡s abiertos a la tecnologÃ­a y empezamos a ver que es la Ãºnica manera de evolucionar. Por ello, no tengo dudas de que la estabilizaciÃ³n por membranas es una tecnologÃ­a de futuro con un potencial tremendoâ€, seÃ±alÃ³ FernÃ¡ndez.
Enomaq nos permitiÃ³ conocer a los representantes de Oenodia en EspaÃ±a, que nos contaran su visiÃ³n tecnolÃ³gica y sus perspectivas de futuro.
En la misma lÃ­nea nos hablaron desde Secovisa, el representante en AndalucÃ­a desde hace 5 aÃ±os: â€œTenemos una zona complicada porque nuestros bodegueros son muy tradicionales y estÃ¡n muy acostumbrados a trabajar con otras tecnologÃ­as y productos, pero ninguno de ellos hace sombra a los rendimientos que se logran con los equipos de Oenodiaâ€, comentaron desde el equipo tÃ©cnico. â€œPoder estabilizar cantidades pequeÃ±as de vino y hacerlo con un consumo energÃ©tico tan bajo es vital y, sin duda, es el futuroâ€.
